Went on after a couple of minutes (https://travis-ci.org/openzipkin/zipkin/jobs/76685357). The first line was that signing the version was completed. It continued at around the time @adriancole manually pushed the publish button on the UI; may or may not be related.
Is signing happening on bintray's side or in Travis?

Bintray. That line is logged at https://github.com/bintray/gradle-bintray-plugin/blob/adb397a261b87e9baff9c264bd1347e61290a3fb/src/main/groovy/com/jfrog/bintray/gradle/BintrayUploadTask.groovy#L301 when https://bintray.com/docs/api/#_gpg_sign_a_version finishes
Cloud be useful to try to get HTTP request logs, maybe `--debug` would do it, or some other workaround

I'll tag again and just wait longer.. Not clicking anywhere. Let's see if
it just finishes.

Actually, could someone else tag? 1.2.1-rc26

Takes a while to finish and I'm afk
@abesto is there a downside to disabling signing in general?

Maven central requires artifacts to be signed.
On Aug 21, 2015 10:10 PM, "R. Tyler Croy" notifications@github.com wrote:

> @abesto https://github.com/abesto is there a downside to disabling
> signing in general?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/644#issuecomment-133547491.

Probably something about security as well :-)

maybe we can add logging to the signing routine? (if they accept pull requests). perhaps our huge jars take a while to sign.
calling this done. 2 successful deploys in a row. Key is to _wait_. Also wait at least 5 minutes before clicking on maven sync button in bintray.

soo.. we did this, and it didn't even take 3 years!

https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/io/zipkin/zipkin-common/1.2.1/
:+1: :cake:
got to go :100:
@dsyer @spencergibb any good choices of env variable name?
Not that I know of. But maybe a `REDIS_[HOST,PORT,PASSWORD]`?

Aggregates are blank for me as well.  I don't know what should appear on the aggregates page, i.e. if I am missing some configuration or if the page is not implemented or something else.  

I'm running Zipkin using the bin/collector, bin/query and bin/web tools.  I can see traces fine on the main query page.

The aggregates api still exists in HBase and Anorm. It is partially
re-implemented in cassandra
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/599/files#diff-d45fcb9231702e1188c7c55289a48c30R19

I understand that none of the apis matter as the hadoop job hasn't
been re-implemented, but even if it was, only cassandra would work?
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-aggregate/issues/2

Regardless, this issue is about anorm. It would be nice to know what
an implementation of the hadoop job would need to do (ex. a unit test
in the aggregate project might help explain this). Even better would
be a non-hadoop answer. For example, some explanation somewhere of
what data must exist for the aggregate UI to operate. I suspect many
won't want to run hadoop, but could process the data in another
fashion.

Thoughts?

I think it's possible to run zipkin-aggregate as a fat jar without hadoop, and it will run in single-node mode. (But I'm not sure really, I can't remember)
If we move to Summingbird, we will get streaming processing, and Summingbird has support for in-memory-processing as well. But then we'd have to rewrite the analysis job - and there are some things you cannot do in streaming jobs that you can do in batch jobs.

We should be able to use [cascading-jdbc](https://github.com/Cascading/cascading-jdbc) for the SQL databases, and [cascading-cassandra](https://github.com/ifesdjeen/cascading-cassandra) (not maintained though :cry:) for Cassandra.
Another option is to setup zipkin-collector with MultiSpanStore and implement a SpanStore that writes to HDFS. Then, we can analyse data from HDFS and we won't need the jdbc/cassandra taps.

It would be best to have dependencies on projects that aren't orphaned
or at risk of being orphaned. Considering the pain of our past, I'd love to 
not have version locking to a specific scala runtime or EOL JRE.

I know that during the workshop, Jason from groupon mentioned their tracing
analysis story would be via Spark. Any insight into why that may or may not
be a good choice for our aggregate functionality? I've not tried this, but
it seems to have an in-memory mode as well.
Parking the discussion on how to implement aggregates here #656, unless we find there's a low-hanging fruit means to implement something for anormdb with current infrastructure.
Can this be closed?

In our current zipkin setup we tweak `log level` (default debug level logs way too much), `queue num workers` and `sample rate`.  By using environment variables it means we also can configure these options when using `docker-zipkin`.
If the environment variables are not specified I use the current default values.
:+1:, maybe could use some simple docs?
@jamescway Agree. I updated `README.md` with explanation of the new configurable parameters.
looks great :)
fyi @jamescway @yurishkuro

@fedj are you saying that you'd like to use a consistency level of LOCAL_ONE rather than ONE?

(it is still possible, and rather simple, but the approach has changed, to edit consistency level used by in the *-cassandra.scala files updating QueryOptions using `withQueryOptions(..)` before the cluster is built.)

@michaelsembwever Yep, basically we tend to use LOCAL_QUORUM and it was possible to change this consistency level by a configuration flag on the command line.
Btw, congrats for the use of the standard cassandra driver.
sorry it is a bit of a mess.. I'll look at this after catching up on change like https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/commit/c69db3bfffb855f766ba1754cfe35e7bcc12fce5
thanks!

Definitely some room for additional work like you mentioned, but sounds like we could revisit.

just one spelling thing otherwise LGTM
Nice! +1
actually there's more to remove.. the only user of `spanStore.getTracesDuration` was ordering!
ok this is much better... far more mileage out of removing support for Order!

Given that existing implementation is based on Finagle, there are a lot of stats already being reported. However, they are not being emitted to any backend in the default configuration, and in fact there seems to be no external configuration mechanism aside from putting a text file in META-INF specifying the class name of the metrics backend.

@adriancole 

> always buffer and use rules based on child spans

Buffer where? Given that spans of a single trace can be reported by different hosts to different collectors, it seems like this would need:
1. consistent hashing to assemble spans of the same trace in a single collector
2. short term storage of all traces, until sampling decision can be made and the trace is either saved or dropped

Is that what you had in mind?
@yurishkuro I didn't have a design in mind, but your thoughts seem to be on the right path

It's showing this:

https://raw.githubusercontent.com/finn-no/zipkin/finn-master/zipkin-finn.png

A map over all the services and how they interact.
Unfortunately, as a side effect of the Cassandra driver rewrite, we lost support for the aggregate job, and I haven't had time (yet) to rewrite it.
I thought the first step would be to make a functioning prototype that runs on Hadoop in docker (with zipkin-docker), but that involves forking Twitter's Bijection library due to some Scala compilation issues.
:+1: just had a non-merge-blocking question
@jamescway yeah.. just verified old UI still works fine (extra unnecessary order param is ignored)
nice :ramen:
rebased, but no other progress
not sure, but we may be able to update to scala 2.11 after this?

Oh, sorry for the lack of response!
+1 LGTM!
It's green! Let's do it! +1
happy
But are we sure Twitter will be able to stay up to date? (Do we care?)
@mosesn safe to assume twitter will be able to build on JDK8 this year, right?
I know zipkin was running on JRE 8 when I left, but yeah building is a different topic. At worst, we could switch the compiler (if not already set) to produce Java 7 bytecode.

ps if we want to decouple, add this to the main build.gradle after apply plugin java

```
    sourceCompatibility = 1.7
    targetCompatibility = 1.7
```
But Twitter runs on the published fat-jars now anyways, right? Developers working on Zipkin can fork the project from GitHub and build locally with JDK8 and Gradle. (Pants is gone anyways)

No twitter doesn't use the fat-jars (or the -service projects at all).
There's an internal TwitterServer, configured by flags, which uses the
Factory approach as opposed to the ostrich stuff.

If zipkin's libraries are source-level 8, then pants (the internal build
tool) would need to run on 1.8 to compile them. @stuhood might know if that
migration is complete.

Regardless, twitter can update to 1.4.0 (released today) as that was still
compiled to target Java 7. cc @CaitieM20
Ok, source compatibility with Java 7 is probably a good idea then. (We won't gain anything by not being source compatible)
@jamescway thanks for updating the settings.. I'll run this locally and see if the classes are built properly.. hang tight!

Nice feature! But could you put the javascript code together with the rest of the javascript? The input box could be mounted as a flight.js component.

This is a documentation bug. Twitter doesn't use cassandra anymore, and regardless, we should bring this up to speed.

configKey=dev is a specific anormdb setup that uses file sharing. We could quite easily add a mysql config based on a jdbc connect string. I've wondered myself why we haven't (that or postgres). I can help fix the doc bug, but can you share a little more about how you'd be deploying this? docker?
